data:
Facsimile Images

Θ(εοῖς) ((ivy-leaf)) Κ(αταχθονίοις) ((ivy-leaf))
Πεσκέννις
Καλάτιχος ((ivy-leaf)) ἔζη-
σεν ((ivy-leaf)) ⸢ἔ⸣τη ((ivy-leaf)) ο ((ivy-leaf)) γ ´ ((ivy-leaf)) μ(ῆνας) γ´ ((ivy-leaf))
5Πεσκ⸢ε⸣ννί⸢α⸣ ((ivy-leaf))
Γ⸢α⸣μι·κὴ ((|)) ⸢ἀ⸣νδρί

Apparatus criticus

Text based on photographs; Franz corrected the phonetic spelling in Καλάτυχος, but Korhonen thinks of a stonecutter’s error for Καλλίτυχος (attested also in Sicily: LGPN 3A: 235)
4: Amico, Torremuzza, Franz: ϙ; Ferrara, Kaibel, Korhonen: ο; Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara, Franz: δ; Kaibel, Korhonen: γ
6: ΓΛΜΙΚΗΙΧΝΔΤΙ lapis; Torremuzza: γαμικὴ γιλυκυτάτη; Ferrara; Korhonen: γαμικὴ ἀνδρί; Kaibel: τ(ῷ) ἀνδρί (less probable τἀνδρί)

English translation

To the subterranean deities. Peskennis Kalatichos lived for 73 years and 3 months. Peskennia Gamike [built this] for her man.

Italian translation

Agli dèi inferi. Peksennis Kalatichos visse per 73 anni e 3 mesi. Peskennia Gamike (costruì questo) per suo marito.

commentary

The epitaph contains the traditional formula Θ(εοῖς) Κ(αταχθονίοις), the name of the deceased, the indication of the age (with ζάω in the aorist form) and a second sentence with the name of the dedicant and the relationship of the deceased with the dedicant in dative. The cognomen of the wife is attested in another inscription from Catania dated to the imperial age, CIL 10.7063 = ISic000347. Both the deceased and the dedicant seem to belong to the Roman gens Pescennia. The text shows multiple diversions from standard orthography, and an extensive and irregular use of hederae.

bibliography

    Amico 1741 257 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002186 Torremuzza 1769 140 n. 37 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002084 Torremuzza 1784 147 n. 41 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002083 Ferrara 1829 350 n. 1 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002005 14.0496 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001072 116 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000028 3.5719 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001252
